bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, August 23, 1953

div1.p: Tate recollects his impressions about the members of the Yellow Fever Board. He encourages Truby to share his memories of Reed with Hench.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, August 23, 1953
div1.opener:
Mailed Aug. 23, '53
Copy
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, 3 California
August 23, 1953
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I am returning with this doctor Hench's letter to you of
August 12th which you favored me with. Will write you as
requested regarding my knowledge of Major Reed and his
Board, which, naturally, is very little and will not be
of any benefit to you or Doctor Hench.

I know nothing about the members of the Board from a per-
sonal standpoint. I very seldom saw Agramonte. The only
time I saw him closely was when he came to Pinar del Rio
to investigate the cause of the many deaths there. I went
through the wards with him and Capt. Godfrey, (whose clerk
I was). I still remember the curious, quissical way he
glanced at Godfrey as he examined some of the patients and
their bed charts. I remember this more than I do his appear-
ance except that he was tall and handsome. I think Major
Reed came a few days later, as I remember him being there.

As I did not arrive at Columbia Barracks until Sept. 9th,
1900, and Lazear became ill Sept. 16th, I knew nothing of
him except hearsay.

My only remembrance of Carroll is of an English heavy-face
type. Mess-room gossip was that he got his medical educa-
tion the hard way and was always willing to take mosquito
tests, so we were for him.

So the above don't mean anything, and I regret it, especi-
ally in view of the fact that in those days I took precise
notice of everyone I met--a habit instilled by newspaper
work. A few years after those events I could have given a
graphic discription of everyone there, but the changes and
events of fifty years have erased it all from my memory,
and I just cant stretch it as “old soldiers” often do!

I saw Major Reed numerous times outdoors, in the Hospital
office of Capt. Stark and once at a post-mortem. All that
I remember of his physical appearance is that he was fairly
tall and slender. It seems to me his hair was slightly red-
dis brown or sandy. (This is not a statement, merely an
impression.) I got no impression of sternness from him--
He seemed more preoccupied and earnest in expression.

Doctor Hench says he does not know how much of personality
should go into his book. He is distressed that he has not
an actual knowledge of Reed and his colleagues. I think I
understand his feeling. His last paragraph tells what he
wishes. He would like to write intimately but never having
known these men, he can write only through the eyes and
minds of others. . And there are no others except your-
self who knew Reed with any degree of personal friendship.

It is of no avail to him to read that a man was dignified,
disciplined, stern, etc. That would apply to very many
older Army officers. Its a type, not a personality. By the
way, if you will excuse the digression, I don't like that
word, “dignified.” Of all the known traits it is the most
easily counterfeited by those who rate pomposity as dignity.
My impression of Reed, superficial though it may be, was
one of Intellectual earnestness.

But, in your outstanding book on this subject one can find
more discriptions of Major Reed, from an intimate source
than I think has been published anywhere else, and Doctor
Hench should be able to derive much from that. But I think
he wants to be in your place and thoughts in some of the
conversations you had with Reed that are merely hinted at
in your book, so that he can see Reed as you, a bright, in-
tellectual, fine young officer, doctor saw him and thought
of him.

He thinks, as I do, that you were offered the place on the
Board vacated by Lazear's death. He knows that the letter
Reed sent you--The first written account of the first case
of experimental Y. F. would not have been sent to anyone
but to one he thought much of. That he was probably instru-
mentalin your being dispatched to Rowell Barracks when they
became suspicious of Y. F. there and where his son was ser-
ving.

He knows from all this that you knew Reed better that any
one else alive and he wants to live with Major Reed vicar-
iously through you. So I think that what you write him on
your association with Major Reed and the others and what
you actually thought of them will be of the greatest im-
portance in writing a factual book of this kind. In fact,
it won't be complete without your contribution.

Well, this is a very lengthy reply to you questions, but
you well know what a garrulous old man I am at a typewriter!
You have never told me how you are getting along now with
your walking. Very well, I sincerely hope. I feel that you
can conquor anything in that line. Fact is you are a great
source of inspiration to me. I'm a regular coward, and when
some unusual ache or pain develops I get scared stiff! Then
I think of what you have been through and conquored and it
braces me up.

With very best wishes to you and family from my wife and
self,
div1.closer: As alwayss sincerely, Paul L. Tate (lencl)
